analytic.title: A multichannel electrochemical all-solid-state wearable potentiometric sensor for real-time sweat ion monitoring

textClass.keywords: Ion selective electrode Wearable sensor Sweat High-quality graphene

div.p: There is considerable interest in wearable potentiometric ion sensors that can provide information about the quality of a person's health by monitoring ion concentration levels in biofluids. Significant progress has been achieved, particularly in device integration. However, the crucial interfacial water layer and the use of transducer materials remain challenging. Herein we report a paper-based, flexible, all-solid-state, ion-selective electrode (ISE) for the real-time analysis of sweat. The super-hydrophobic paper matrix was modified with a fluorinated alkyl silane to reduce the water-layer effect. We used a high-quality graphene suspension with high conductivity and capacitance as an ion-to-electron transducer, which further stabilized the potential. The integrated solid ISE has four channels that can detect K + , Na + , Cl -and pH simultaneously. This wearable potentiometric sensor has reliable accuracy, good potential stability and low detection limits, and could be used in healthcare and clinical analysis.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Improper diet and high-intensity sports can cause changes in ion concentration levels, leading to physiological disorders [1]. For instance, eating bananas on an empty stomach can result in a sudden increase in the level of potassium ions in the body, which might cause dizziness, vomiting and dyspnea. Ion-level abnormalities could also indicate diseases, such as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia, which may result in damage to the heart, liver and kidneys [2]. Monitoring ion concentrations in the body is thus crucial to evaluating a person's health. Wearable sensors have exhibited the potential for non-invasive chemical/electrochemical analysis of biofluids, such as tears, saliva and sweat, for disease diagnosis [3,4], drug detection [5], and athletic performance optimization [6].

All-solid-state ion-selective electrodes (ISEs) are a type of electrochemical potentiometric sensor characterized by a solid junction, fast response, miniaturization and integration [7][8][9]. Unlike traditional liquid-junction electrodes, solid ISEs can be integrated into flexible, wearable devices for ion sensing. The key issue is potential stability. Other important factors are the hydrophobicity of the material (waterlayer effect) and the interfacial capacitance (electric double-layer and/ or redox capacitances) between the transducer and the ion-selective membrane (ISM) [10,11]. A few carbon-based ion-to-electron transducer materials have been investigated, including ordered three-dimensional porous carbon [12,13], carbon nanotubes [14][15][16][17], and chemically reduced graphene oxide [18][19][20]. One of the advantages of these carbon-based materials is that they can be readily dispersed in solvents to produce ink suspensions, which can then easily be transferred to various substrates. Andrade et al. reported a paper-based ISE using carbon nanotube ink as the transducer material [21]. This work proposed a new method for fabricating a low-cost ISE sensor platform. Qin and co-workers proposed flexible, three-dimensional, paper-based ISEs with carbon ink as the transducer material for potentiometric biosensing [22]. This sensor detects biological analytes, including proteins and small molecules, rather than ions. This paper-based device is portable and flexible and so has potential applications in wearable sensors. Significant progress has been achieved in ex situ detection but real-time multi-ion analysis of biofluids remains a challenge.

In this work, we introduce a multichannel paper-based ISE for the real-time analysis of ions in human sweat. The paper-based substrate has previously demonstrated high levels of flexibility and conductivity [21,22], making it a good candidate for wearable electrochemical sensors. The hydrophobicity of the paper substrate was improved through modification with a fluorinated alkyl silane. A high-quality graphene suspension was sprayed onto the paper electrode as a high capacitance transducer with hydrophobic properties, which significantly reduces the water-layer effect. This high-quality graphene, directly exfoliated from graphite, has high conductivity and hydrophobicity compared with chemically reduced graphene oxide (RGO). The resulting multichannel ISE can simultaneously detect Na + , K + , Cl -, and pH in sweat with reliable accuracy, good potential stability and low detection limits.

div.head: Reagents and materials
div.p: The potassium ionophore (Valinomycin), sodium ionophore (X), chloride ionophore (II), hydrogen ionophore (I), 2-nitrophenyl octyl ether (NOPE), tridodecylmethylammonium chloride, bis(2-ethylhexyl) sebacate (DOS), potassium tetrakis(4-chlorophenyl)borate (KTClPB), sodium tetrakis-[3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)phenyl]borate (NaTFPB), high molecular weight polyvinyl chloride (PVC), tridodecylmethylammonium chloride (TDMACl), a fluorinated alkyl silane (CF 3 (CF 2 ) 7 CH 2 CH 2 SiCl 3 , C 10 F ) and ascorbic acid (AA) were all obtained from Sigma-Aldrich. Tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethanol, hydrochloric acid (HCl), potassium chloride (KCl), sodium chloride (NaCl), silver chloride powder (AgCl), disodium hydrogen phosphate (Na 2 HPO 4 ), disodium phosphate dodecahydrate (NaH 2 PO 4 ) and glucose were purchased from Shanghai Chemicals, China. All aqueous solutions were prepared with ultrapure water from a Milli-Q Plus system (Millipore). Chromatography paper (Whatman chromatography No.1 paper) was purchased from GE Healthcare UK Limited.

div.head: Preparation of super-hydrophobic paper electrode substrate
div.p: 20 μL C 10 F was put in a Petri dish with the paper electrode substrate fixed at the bottom. This dish was then transferred into a vacuum drying chamber at 80 °C for 30 min to evaporate the C 10 F so that it uniformly coated the surface of the paper electrode substrate [23].

div.head: Fabrication of multichannel paper-based ISEs
div.p: High-quality graphene was synthesized as described in our previous report [24]. It was dispersed ultrasonically in ethanol for 1 h, then filtered using a stainless-steel mesh. 1 mL graphene solution (5 mg/mL) was than sprayed onto the modified C 10 F paper through a stainless-steel mask. Subsequently, Na + , K + , Cl -, H + and reference membrane cocktails were dropped on the graphene electrode (denoted as Na + -GPE, K + -GPE, Cl --GPE, H + -GPE and R-GPE, respectively), then dried in air at room temperature overnight. The K + -selective membrane cocktail was prepared by dissolving 200 mg of a mixture containing (in wt%) 0.55% of KTClPB, 1% of valinomycin (molar ratio of KTClPB:valinomycin is 1:1.23), 65.45% of PVC and 33% of DOS in 1.5 mL THF. The Na + -selective membrane cocktail was prepared by dissolving 200 mg of a mixture containing (in wt%) 0.55% NaTFPB, 1% sodium ionophore (X) (molar ratio of NaTFPB:sodium ionophore (X) is 0.62:1), 65.45% PVC and 33% DOS in 1.5 mL THF. The H + selective membrane cocktail was prepared by dissolving 200 mg of a mixture containing (in wt%) 0.5% NaTFPB, 1% hydrogen ionophore (I) (molar ratio of NaTFPB:hydrogen ionophore (I) is 0.3:1), 66% PVC, and 32.5% DOS in 1.5 mL THF [25]. The Cl -selective membrane cocktail was prepared by dissolving 151.65 mg of a mixture containing (in wt%) 0.1% TDMACl, 1% chloride ionophore(II) (molar ratio of TDMACl:chloride ionophore(II) is 0.17:1), 33% PVC, and 65.9% NOPE in 1.5 mL THF [26]. The reference selective membrane cocktail was prepared by dissolving 200 mg of a mixture containing (in wt%) 0.9% KTClPB, 1.1% TDMACl, 30% PVC and 68% DOS in 2 mL THF. 15.6 mg of powdered AgCl containing traces of spontaneously formed metallic Ag and 40.3 mg of solid KCl were further added into the THF mixture [27]. For comparison, a K + -ISE based on a commercially available glassy carbon electrode (K + -GCE) was prepared by dropping the K + membrane cocktail onto a polished GCE.

div.head: Material characterization
div.p: Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained using a FE-SEM (Philips XL30 ESEM-FEG integrated with an EDAX system) at an accelerating voltage of 10.0 kV. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw Raman system model 2000 spectrometer using a 514.5 nm argon ion laser. A M6 handheld four-probe meter was used to measure the electrical resistance of the electrode.

div.head: Electromotive force (EMF) measurements
div.p: The potentiometric measurements were conducted at room temperature (25 ± 2 °C) using a CHI760 Electrochemical Workstation. The working electrodes were the ISEs fabricated as described above. The reference electrode was Ag|AgCl (3 M KCl). A platinum wire was used as a counter electrode. The tests on the real samples were carried out using a Multichannel Electrochemical Workstation. The measured potential was calibrated for the liquid-junction potentials, and the activities were calculated according to the Debye-Hückel equation.

div.head: Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS)
div.p: A Solartron 1255B Frequency Response Analyzer (Solartron Inc., UK) was used to perform the EIS experiments. The measurements were carried out under the open circuit potential with a frequency range from 0.1 Hz to 100 KHz, and the AC amplitude was 200 mV. The K + -GPE and K + -GCE electrodes were chosen for the EIS tests to evaluate the ion-to-electron transducer performance.

div.head: Chronopotentiometric measurements
div.p: Constant anodic and cathodic currents (1 nA) were applied to evaluate the short-term potential stability of the K + -GPE and K + -GCE electrodes.

div.head: Real sample application
div.p: A healthy, active female volunteer was asked to cycle at a steady speed until sweat was produced. The ISE sensor was then pasted on her upper right arm to determine the concentrations of K + , Cl -, Na + and pH simultaneously. The potentiometric data were analyzed using Labview software. For comparison, sweat samples were collected and analyzed by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS, ThermoScientific Xseries II).

div.head: Fabrication and characterization of the paper-based ISEs
div.p: The fabrication procedure for the ISEs is shown in Fig. 1. The paper substrate was first chemically functionalized with C 10 F to make the surface super-hydrophobic in order to reduce the water-layer effect (Fig. 1a). Then a 1 mL graphene suspension (5 mg/mL) was sprayed onto the modified paper at 80 °C using a mask (Fig. 1b). After functionalization, the water forms droplets on the surface and the contact angle is up to 147 o (Fig. 1c). The super-hydrophobic paper provides resistance to wetness in the test process, minimizes the air-water-solid interaction energy and makes the graphene suspension spread uniformly over the surface. Furthermore, the super-hydrophobic performance also avoids the external diffusion of the graphene cocktail solution. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was used to characterize the prepared ISE. As shown in Fig. 1e, there is a distinct boundary between the graphene electrode and the paper substrate. The graphene appears wrinkled with a high surface roughness, which greatly improves the capacitance of the electrode (Fig. 1f), which is beneficial to the potential stability. The thicknesses of the ion-selective membrane (ISM) and graphene electrode were determined as 950 μm and 114 μm, respectively (Fig. 1g and h).

The conductivity and flexibility of the prepared ISE were then examined (Fig. 2). To confirm the quality of the graphene, Raman spectra were recorded and compared with those of reduced graphene oxide (RGO) (Fig. 2a). The sp 2 carbon atoms breathing mode (D and G bands) were observed for both RGO and graphene. However, the D/G values for the RGO and graphene are 0.77 and 0.042, respectively, which demonstrates that there are many fewer defects in the high-quality graphene [28,29]. The electrical resistance is a function of the number of spraying cycles on the modified paper (Fig. 2b). With just one layer the resistance is high but then significantly decreases upon further spraying. After five spraying cycles, the resistance reaches approximately 150 Ω.

The prepared ISE also has good mechanical flexibility (Fig. 2c): it can be bent several times with only tiny changes in the resistance and electromotive force (EMF). As shown in Fig. 2d, after being bent by 30°, 60°, and 90°the EMF shows a maximum drift of 4 mV, with a drift in the resistance of 35 Ω. Furthermore, the resistance and the EMF remained almost unchanged after being repeatedly bent (30 times). These results indicate that the prepared ISE has good conductivity and flexibility.

div.head: Electrochemical characterization of the paper-based ISE
div.p: The performance of the prepared ISE was examined in a series of electrochemical tests. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the K + -GPE and K + -GCE was carried out in 0.1 M KCl (Fig. 3a). Both impedance spectra display high-frequency semicircles, which are related to the bulk resistance of the ISE membrane (R bulk ) [14,30]. An equivalent circuit was designed to fit the experimental data (inset, Fig. 3a). The circuit is composed of a solution resistance (R s ), an interfacial constant phase element (CPE) in parallel with a bulk membrane resistance (R bulk ), and a classical Warburg diffusion element (Z w ). The value of R bulk decreased from 0.17 MΩ (K + -GCE) to 0.13 MΩ (K + -GPE), suggesting that the high-quality graphene serving as transducer enhances the ion-to-electron charge transfer. This effect is similar to the conducting polymer transducer (e.g., polypyrrole, PPY) reported previously [30], in which the PPY facilitated charge transport from the ISE membrane to the electrode.

Current reversal chronopotentiometry was carried out to estimate the capacitance and short-term potential stability of the prepared electrode (Fig. 3b). On applying a constant current of 1 nA to the K + -GCE and K + -GPE, the potential values of the electrodes were recorded, and the resistance calculated from the potential jump. Using the ratio ∆E/∆t, the potential drift of the K + -GCE is 5.73 × 10 -3 V/s and the K + -GPE is 3.3 × 10 -5 V/s. From the fundamental capacitor equation (I = C × ∆E∆t), the value of the electrical capacitance of the K + -GPE is 34.7 μF compared with 0.6 μF for K + -GCE, indicating that the K + -GPE has better potential stability.

Since a film of water at the interface between the ISM and electrode substrate significantly affects the potential stability, water-layer tests were carried out (Fig. 3c). The open circuit potentials (OCP) of the K + -GPE and K + -GCE were measured in 0.1 M KCl solution for 1 h; the electrodes were then moved into 0.1 M NaCl solution for 2 h, and finally returned to the 0.1 M KCl solution for several hours. As shown in Fig. 3c, the K + -GCE maintains its initial potential but shows continuous drift. However, the potential of K + -GPE is stable throughout the test. The super-hydrophobic property of the K + -GPE stops the formation of a water layer, leading to high potential stability. This was further demonstrated by a long-term study of potential drift which showed a small positive drift of 0.18 mV/h over a test period of 12 h.

div.head: Potentiometric performances
div.p: The potential responses of the prepared ISE electrodes were measured in aqueous solutions containing the cations and anions of interest in concentrations from 10 -7 M to 1 M (Fig. 4). The potentiometric time traces and calibration curves of the K + -GCE, K + -GPE, Na + -GPE, Cl --GPE and H + -GPE are shown in Fig. 4a-e. We first examined the potential response of the K + -GCE to provide a basis for comparison. The slope was determined to be 49.4 ± 0.58 mV/decade (R 2 = 0.9952) and the linear range from 10 -1 M to 10 -5 M (Fig. 4a). The slope is less than the Nernst response since there is no transducer layer, resulting in potential drift at low concentrations of K + . If the linear range is reduced to 10 -1 M to 10 -4 M, the slope increases to 52.0 ± 0.53 mV/ decade (R 2 = 0.9990). For the K + -GPE, the response slope is 57.0 ± 0.25 mV/decade (R 2 = 0.9994) with a linear range from 10 -1 M to 10 -6 M (Fig. 4b), illustrating the benefits of the graphene transducer. Since there are multiple ions in sweat, Na + and Cl -were also tested, giving Nernstian slopes of 55.7 ± 0.08 mV/decade and 56.7 ± 0.28 mV/decade, respectively. The linear range is from 10 -1 M to 10 -6 M, which is suitable for detection in sweat. Fig. 4e illustrates the potential response time trace of the H + -GPE in solution with pH values from 4 to 7.5, which also shows a Nernstian response (56 ± 0.58 mV/decade).

There are many complex components in sweat which might affect the response. To mimic the sweat environment, an anti-interference test was performed by adding certain concentrations of CaCl 2 , HCl, glucose and AA (Fig. 4f). No apparent potential drift was observed. Overall, the above results demonstrate that the graphene-based ISE has high sensitivity and selectivity, a wide linear range and good potential stability.

div.head: Monitoring ions in sweat
div.p: To monitor the ions present in sweat, we recruited a volunteer who exercised for 1 h. The sensor was connected to a conductor which on the other side was connected to the Labview system, with multichannel data being transferred instantaneously, as shown in Fig. 5a. The realtime data corresponding to the amounts of K + , Na + , Cl -present and the pH of the sweat are shown in Fig. 5b. The signals are stable. The concentrations of target ions were measured as follows: K + (≈6.5 mM), Na + (≈49.5 mM), Cl -(≈61.4 mM) and pH (≈6.91). For comparison, the sweat was collected by centrifuging and analyzed by ICP-MS (Fig. 5c). The accuracy of the real-time ISE detection was calculated to be K + (90%), Na + (88.4%), Cl -(87.6%) and pH (88.7%).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: We fabricated a multichannel, wearable ISE sensor for the real-time detection of multiple ions in human sweat. The sensor exhibits good potential stability, has low detection limits and a wide linear range by virtue of the super-hydrophobic paper substrate and high-quality graphene transducer. Multiple channels have been designed to simultaneously detect K + , Na + Cl -and pH with reliable accuracy. This ISE sensor system could be further improved, for example by constructing a micro-or nano-scale skin-fit sensor chip that tests more ions simultaneously. It could also be integrated with a self-powered unit and combined with mobile devices for in situ analysis in healthcare and clinical research.

figure.head: Fig. 1 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 1. (a-d) A schematic representation of the fabrication of paper-based ISEs. (e) SEM images of the paper substrate and graphene electrode. (f) SEM image of the graphene morphology. (g, h) SEM images showing the thicknesses of the ISM and graphene electrode, respectively.

figure.head: Fig. 2 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. (a) Raman spectra of RGO and graphene. (b) The relationship between the conductivity and the thickness of the graphene electrode. The inset shows the resistance measured by a handheld probe meter. (c) A photograph of the prepared electrode bent outward by 60°. (d) Resistance and EMF for cycles of bending at different angles (30°, 60°, 90°).

figure.head: Fig. 3 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. (a) Impedance spectra of the K + -GPE and the K + -GCE in 0.1 M KCl. (b) Current reversal chronopotentiometry test of the K + -GPE and the K + -GCE in 0.1 M KCl. (c) Water-layer test of the K + -GPE and the K + -GCE. (d) Potential drift of the K + -GPE over 12 h in 0.1 M KCl.

figure.head: Fig. 4 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. (a-e) The open-circuit potential responses and calibration curves of the K + -GCE, K + -GPE, Na + -GPE, Cl --GPE and H + -GPE. (f) The interference test for the Na + -GPE.

figure.head: Fig. 5 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 5. (a) Photograph of the detection device. (b) Results of real-time monitoring of the concentration of target ions and pH in sweat. (c) Comparison of ex situ sweat analysis results with the real-time test sample readings (Ex-situ sweat sample a was measured by electrochemical workstation and Ex-situ sweat sample b was measured by ICP-MS).

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 21527806, 21627809, 21727815 and 21805052) and the Guangdong Science and Technology Department (No.2019B010933001).
